fields.title: Enamel Cross Project
fields.description:
The project is to design and make an enamel cross alter piece 14 inches tall to be placed in a chapel. The chapel, although indoors, is still a bit exposed to temperature and climate variations.

The cross itself is to be of a medieval design.

fields.title: Cloisonné Enamel Doorknobs Project
fields.description:
This was a commission to produce 26 cloisonné enamel cabinet doorknobs for a handmade kitchen.

MORE PHOTOS COMING WHEN I'VE SORTED THEM OUT!

fields.title: Rectangular Enamel Box
fields.description:
The lid and the base are made from copper which has been press formed into shape. The mount is machined from solid brass plate and then polished to give a lasting shine.

The actual dimensions of the box (including the mount) are 84mm x 66mm with 31mm height. There may be some slight variation as all the boxes and mounts are individually crafted.

fields.title: Tribute to Anthony Phillips
fields.description:
I worked for Tony from 1994 to 1999 and completed an appreticeship in enamel painting under his guidance. He passed away in 2012 at the age of 66 and will be sadly missed. During his carreer he painted many paintings and designs, primarily enamels for Halcyon Days Enamels.

I have put together this gallery of paintings that are taken from a photo album that Tony kept. These are by no means the best of the many years, just the ones that I could find. If you have in your possession a painting by Tony then I would be happy to show it in this gallery, please email me at mark@mdmorris.co.uk.

fields.title: Blue and Red Letter S Cloisonné Enamel Doorknob by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
This is the second letter-S cloisonné piece. The red is transparent, but quite deep so the transparency only becomes apparent when it catches the light - surprise!

The enamel disc diameter is 25mm.

fields.title: Cloisonné Doorknob showing the Château Pontet-Canet Label
fields.caption:
This enamel piece shows the Château with the vineyard in the foreground. The vineyards were achieved with textured silver strips with spaces in between.

The enamel piece is 30mm in diameter and is set into an oak doorknob.

fields.title: Clos Des Papes Wine Bottle Cloisonné enamel by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
Cloisonné Enamel depicting a bottle of Clos Des Papes 2001. A mixture of opaque and transparent enamel are used to enhance the image.

This enamel is 30mm in diameter.

fields.title: Farm House Miniature Painting and Cloisonné Enamel
fields.caption:
This miniature painting has cloisonné sections for the sky, house, drive and grass. I used the Milton Bridge British Enamels pallet for this cloisonné work and I found the painting has a softness when using this enamel set. Inside this house is the kitchen where the doorknobs will go.

The enamel diameter is 30mm.

fields.title: Flames Letter V Cloisonné Enamel Doorknob
fields.caption:
The letter V done in flames. I just love the way this one turned out! This personalized door knob uses cloisonné enamelling technique. 

The enamel diameter is 40mm.

fields.title: Cloisonné Enamel Doorknob showing a Gold Pret-a-Manger Star with Opal Background
fields.caption: Cloisonné Enamel doorknob of a gold Pret-a-Manger Star. This star has an opal white background done using opalescent clear flux. The enamel diameter is 30mm.

fields.title: Gold Pret a Manger Star Doorknob in Cloisonné Enamel
fields.caption: Gold Pret a Manger Star done in cloisonne enamel with gold foil inset into the silver rimmed star. The enamel piece is set into an oak doorknob and is 30mm in diameter.

fields.title: Heart Surrounding the Letter M design by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
Cloisonné enamel design of a heart surrounding the letter M. The sparkle is done by milling a star pattern into the underlying silver - leaving the tool marks in the silver. The piece is set into an oak doorknob.

The enamel diameter is 40mm.

fields.title: Large Cloisonne Doorknob collection by Mark Morris
fields.caption: All eight of the large cloisonné door knobs together. For this set, each of the enamel disc inserts is 40mm.

fields.title: Letter-L cloisonné enamel door knob by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
This personalized design started out taking inspiration from the contours of a piece of polished stone, however, it ended up looking more like a piece of graffiti art - which I quite liked! It's a playful design that uses a mix of transparent and opaque enamels.

The piece is set into an oak doorknob and is 40mm in diameter.

fields.title: Illuminated Letter-L Cloisonné Enamel by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
The letter L cloisonné enamel doorknob done in the style inspired by illuminated manuscript. The transparent copper coloured enamel to the right of the L has gold foil underlying it to give it a warmer tone.

The enamel diameter is 40mm.

fields.title: Side view of Letter-L cloisonné enamel door knob by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
From the side view it's possible to pick out some of the gold wire to the left of the L.

The enamel diameter is 40mm.

fields.title: Cloisonné letter L graffiti art, top view
fields.caption: Enamel diameter is 40mm.

fields.title: Cloisonné Letter M with a nice sandwich effect background
fields.caption:
A personalized doorknob with the letter M. The cloisonné wires and base metal are done in silver. The background design shows alternating transparent and opaque enamel.

The enamel piece is 25mm in diameter and set into an oak doorknob.

fields.title: Cloisonné Letter M - side view
fields.caption: The enamel diameter is 25mm.

fields.title: Letter-M with Ladybird on a Leaf
fields.caption:
This cloisonné doorknob shows a ladybird on top of some long leaves that form the letter M.

The leaves are done with transparent peridot green enamel with gold wire for the central stem of the leaves. The veins of the leaves are done by scratching them into the underlying silver base metal.

The enamel diameter is 40mm.

fields.title: Letter-M Cloisonné Enamel with Twirls by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
A letter-M design with a lovely tangerine orange background that I like very much! The entwining proved quite difficult as they made the M segment in many places.

This 25mm diameter cloisonné piece was inset into one of the smaller oak doorknobs.

fields.title: Letter-N Cloisonné Enamel Doorknob by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
An enamel piece for the letter N done using cloisonné technique. This particular piece uses three different thicknesses of silver wire.

The piece is 40mm in diameter and is fixed into an oak doorknob.

fields.title: Second Letter-N Cloisonné Enamel Design by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
The letter N cloisonné enamel is set into a carefully machined oak doorknob recess to give a tight fit. The base metal is fine silver that has been formed to the same shape as the doorknob so that the domed profile of the doorknob continues over the enamel.

The enamel diameter is 40mm.

fields.title: Letter-N Cloisonné Enamel Doorknob by Mark Morris - side view
fields.caption: The enamel diameter is 40mm.

fields.title: Cloisonné Letter S by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
This doorknob is personalized with the letter S. It's done in a Ferrari red and has hints of dashboard controls.

The enamel disc diameter is 25mm.

fields.title: Cloisonné Letter V by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
This doorknob has the letter V done in Cloissoné enamel onto a silver disc base metal. The disc is then inserted into the oak door knob giving a really tight fit.

The enamel disc diameter is 40mm.

fields.title: Opaque Red Pret a Manger Star Cloisonné Enamel Doorknob
fields.caption: The Pret a Manger Star done in opaque red enamel and set into an oak doorknob and is 30mm in diameter.

fields.title: Red and White Grapes Cloisonné Enamel by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
Cloisonné Enamel doorknob showing a close-up of some red and white grapes. The piece uses a mixture of transparent enamel and opaque.

I left this design until last as I wasn't too sure about it, I thought it might end up looking like a lot of Smarties! As it turned out it's one of my favourite pieces, Smarties or grapes, it looks great either way! 

The enamel is 40mm in diameter.

fields.title: Red and White Grapes Cloisonné Enamel - side view
fields.caption: The enamel disc is 40mm in diameter.

fields.title: Transparent Red Cloisonné Enamel Pret-a-Manger Star
fields.caption:
This transparent version of the Pret-a-Manger star has a milling pattern on the underlying silver giving it a sparkle.

Enamel diameter is 30mm.

fields.title: Wine Carafe Cloisonné Enamel by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
Cloisonné enamel doorknob of a large bottomed wine carafe. The carafe is done using mainly transparent colours with gold foil behind. You can see quite a lot of texture on the emerald green section which comes from the gold foil.

The enamel is 30mm in diameter.

fields.title: All the doorknobs together on the kitchen table
fields.caption: The whole set of cabinet doorknobs finished. It's not the best photograph as it's hard to get them all in focus but I thought it was worth including this photo too.

fields.title: Grapes Cloisonné Enamel Doorknob by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
Cloisonné enamel doorknob showing a bunch of red grapes. The doorknob is for a handmade oak kitchen cabinet.

The enamel diameter is 30mm.

fields.title: Cloisonné Ladybird by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
Cloisonné Doorknob of a ladybird using a mixture of opaque and transparent enamel. The opaque tends to bring the subject to the foreground, whereas transparent gives the impression of in the background.

The enamel diameter is 30mm.

fields.title: Medium Sized Cloisonné Doorknobs Set - angled view
fields.caption: This angled view gives a reasonably good representation to the shape of the doorknobs. The curvature of the enamel section matches the curvature of the oak doorknob into which it is set.

fields.title: Medium Sized Cloisonné Doorknobs Set
fields.caption: All of the medium sized doorknobs together. For this set, each of the silver enamel disc inserts are 30mm in diameter.

fields.title: Pouring Wine Cloisonné Enamel by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
Cloisonné enamel piece showing red wine being poured into a glass, and splashing a bit! This piece turned out better than expected. This doorknob is one of the medium sized ones and is set into oak, the oak itself is stained and polished.

The enamel diameter is 30mm.

fields.title: Pouring Wine Cloisonné Enamel by Mark Morris - side view
fields.caption:
Here's the red wine pouring peice again. I thought I'd show it again at this angle as it captures the sparkle in the border where I've used transparent amber coloured enamel and you can see the silver coming through.

The enamel diameter is 30mm.

fields.title: Set of small sized doorknobs by Mark Morris
fields.caption: The set of four small-sized cloisonné enamel doorknobs. Each of the enamel discs in this set is 25mm.

fields.title: Vine Leaves Cloisonné Enamel Doorknob by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
The three vine leaves are done with silver outline and gold veins  Transparent enamel is used for the leaves and the background is very deep blue - almost black, but glows when it picks up the light.

The enamel diameter is 30mm.

fields.title: Cloisonné Wine Glass Enamel by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
A picture of a wine glass done in cloisonné enamel. The enamel is set into an oak doorknob. This was the first successful cloisonné piece that I did. The red enamel is on top of gold foil and the foil is not placed in flat, this was not intentional! However it gave the wine a more realistic effect, with the tone changing depending on the angle of view.

The enamel diameter is 30mm

fields.title: A Baby Girl Enamel Portrait Miniature by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
This miniature baby girl portrait was a Christening gift.

Actual painting size is 62mm x 82mm.

fields.title: A Baby Girl Enamel Portrait Miniature in presentation box
fields.caption: Here's the baby girl enamel portrait miniature in a presentation box.

fields.title: Portrait of Countess Golovine - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
Hand painted reproduction of a painting by Élisabeth Vigée-Le Brun: Portrait of Countess Golovine. The original painting is on show at the Barber Institute of Fine Arts, the University of Birmingham, England. This enamel was a present for my wife after I promised to paint it for her soon after we met when we were both students, ten years later I finally got round to painting it!

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: Country Cottage - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
Enamel commissioned painting of a lovely little country house. This was a commission for Halcyon Days Enamels (via Anthony Phillips) on one of their small oval boxes.

Actual painting size is 69mm x 45mm.

fields.title: Inside Base Labradors - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
This is the inside of the enamel box base that accompanied the Large Country House enamel lid. It's difficult to photograph clearly but shows two Labradors and a bridge covered in white Wisteria.

Actual painting size is 64mm x 43mm.

fields.title: Large Country House - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
This was a commission for Penny Walkinshaw, the managing director of Chelsea Enamels. There was also a painting on the inside base (somewhere in the gallery) of two Labradors and a bridge covered in Wisteria. 

Actual painting size is 64mm x 43mm.

fields.title: Large Luxury Yacht - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
Commissioned miniature enamel painting onto an enamel box lid of a Luxury Yacht. This is the first enamel I painted. I remember it being particularly difficult to get the radar sphere the right size as it involved scratching away the blue sky after the paint had dried.

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: Large Three Storey House - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
An enamel miniature painting of a large three storey house onto an enamel box lid. This painting was for a customer in the USA and the commission came via Halcyon Days Enamels.

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: Oliver, A Toddler Portrait Miniature Enamel Painting side view
Oliver, A Toddler Portrait Miniature Enamel Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
A painting of my son Oliver when he was two and a half years old. This box was a Christmas present for my mum last year (2012). The red colour proved to be particularly difficult to capture with many firings required.

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: Salmon Pink House - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
An enamel miniature painting of a salmon pink coloured house. The trees in the foreground created quite complicated shadows on the brickwork. The salmon pink was a difficult colour to get with the enamels and had to be achieved using cadmium based enamel paints.

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: Terrace at Sainte Adresse by Monet - Commissioned Miniature Painting Enamel Box
fields.caption:
A hand painted reproduction of the painting by Monet. This was one of many reproductions I did, in conjunction with Anthony Phillips, for Halcyon Day based on paintings by the Great Masters. Other paintings included:

  • the Tropical Storm with a Tiger by Henri Rousseau
  • Starry Night by Vincent van Gogh
  • The Cafe Terrace at Night by Vincent van Gogh
  • The Jetty at the Mouth of the Grand Canal, Venice by Boudin

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: Tiger Moths Biplanes - Miniature Enamel Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption: Tiger Moths Biplanes - Miniature Enamel Painting by Mark D Morris A miniature enamel painting, onto the lid of a rectangular enamel box, of two Tiger Moths: one red (G-ANEL) and the other blue (G-ANDE), parked on an airfield. I was really pleased with the way this painting turned out. The sky just looked great and the perspective seemed to work well. Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: Vintage 1926 Bentley 3 Litre - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
Enamel miniature painting of a Vintage Bentley with a green body. Cars tend to look fantastic when painting in enamel as the shiny surface of the enamel does justice to the metallic paint on the car.

 

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: Vintage 1924 Bentley 3 Litre - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
A miniature painting in enamel of a 1924 Bentley, 3 litre, with green body and red interior. It has 9' 9 1/2" wheelbase, high compression engine, twin S.U. carburettors. This Bentley was first owned by Thomas Elder Barr Smith.

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: Westmount - Miniature Enamel Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
This is a miniature painting onto enamel of my childhood home. The house is situated in the beautiful spa town of Buxton, in the Peak District, England. This enamel was a gift for my parents.

Actual painting size is 60mm x 44mm.

fields.title: Caboose - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
An enamel miniature painting, onto an oval hinged enamel box, of a North American Rail-road Caboose. This particular one had been lovingly restored.

Actual painting size is 69mm x 45mm.

fields.title: Mother and Child Family Portrait, Painting in Enamel by Mark D Morris
fields.caption: An enamel portrait miniature of Mother & Child. This was a present for the child's Grandma.

fields.title: Mother and Son Family Portrait Miniature Enamel Box by MDMorris
fields.caption: The side view of the portrait shows the box base, mount and lid together. The base colour came out of the firing with a particularly pleasing blue copper scorch mark coming up from underneath. This was unexpected but gave a very nice effect.

fields.title: Children Paddling - Enamel Miniature Painting Reproduction by Mark D Morris & Anthony Phillips
fields.caption:
A hand painted miniature reproduction, in enamel, of the painting by Phillip Wilson Steer (1891). This was a collaboration with Anthony Phillips. The painting was one of the boxes in the series of replicas of the famous works of great masters done for Halcyon Days Enamels.

Actual size is 73mm x 51mm.

fields.title: Country House - side view
Country House - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
Commissioned miniature painting in enamel of an English country house. This was a great house to paint, very charming! It was a gift from a husband to his wife and the commission came via Anthony Phillips and Halcyon Days Enamels.

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: House Wall Plaque - Miniature Enamel Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
An enamel miniature painting of a house set into a wooden oval shaped frame which can be hung. This enamel was commissioned for Halcyon Days which was received via Anthony Phillips.

Overall dimensions are 105mm x 85mm.

fields.title: Inside the Royal Operal House - Commissioned Miniature Painting Enamel Box
fields.caption:
A view from inside the Royal Opera House. This was a collaboration with Anthony Phillips. It was commissioned personally by Susan Benjamin, the founder of Halcyon Days Enamels.

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

© MDMorris & Anthony Phillips.

fields.title: Jaguar e-type - Miniature Enamel Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
An enamel miniature painting, onto a medium sized enamel box lid, of a red e-type classic Jaguar car. The red colour can be difficult to achieve in enamel as it tends to fade when firing. The red on this painting was achieved by building up the red colour in the last couple of firings.

Actual painting size is 64mm x 43mm.

fields.title: Speed Boat Box - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
Miniature commission, in enamel, for Halcyon Days Enamels (via Anthony Phillips). I was commissioned this in 2010 and was one of the first enamels I did in my new studio.

Actual painting size is 69mm x 45mm.

fields.title: Luxury Speed Boat - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
Commissioned miniature painting onto an enamel box of a luxury speed boat. I got a bit carried away with this one as I wasn't supposed to include the cliffs. I received this commission through Anthony Phillips and he had to etch the cliffs off before sending it to Halcyon Days. This painting was featured in the Halcyon Days Spring 2011 Catalogue! (p27).

Actual painting size is 69mm x 45mm.

fields.title: Luxury Yacht - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
Enamel painting in miniature of a Luxury Yacht onto an enamel box lid. The sea can be quite tricky to capture, especially since some of the boat reflects in the broken surface.

Actual painting size is 69mm x 45mm.

fields.title: Moorlands - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
A commissioned miniature painting in enamel, onto a large rectangular hinged enamel box, of a large house. This particular piece has a banner with the property name inscription on the lid.

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: Poolside - Enamel Miniature Painting by Anthony Phillips & Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
This was one of a collection of about eight commissions for a single costumer, through Halcyon Days, all depicting houses. It was a great order to do since all the properties were different and some quite unusual - like this one. This particular painting was a collaboration with Anthony Phillips.

Actual painting size is 69mm x 45mm.

© MDMorris & Anthony Phillips.

fields.title: Red Mercedes - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
Commissioned miniature painting onto an enamel box lid of a red Mercedes. This was a commission for Halcyon Days onto one of their medium size rectangular boxes. I really enjoy painting cars, the reflections on the car body really make it come alive!

Actual painting size is 64mm x 43mm.

fields.title: Red Mercedes with Background - Miniature Enamel Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
An enamel miniature painting, onto a large rectangular lid of an enamel box, of a red Mercedes. This was a commission for Halcyon Days Enamels which I received via Anthony Phillips, the enamel artist for Halcyon Days.

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: Russian Postcard Scene - Enamel Miniature Painting by Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
A hand painted reproduction of a Russian postcard scene. The scene was painted onto a large rectangular hinged enamel box and looked great! This was quite an unusual commission, which I did in conjunction with Anthony Phillips for Halcyon Days Enamels.

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: Space Shuttle Discovery - An enamel miniature painting by Mark Morris
fields.caption:
A miniature painting of the Space Shuttle Discovery. I was always fascinated by space craft as a child and I remember making a wooden model of Colombia after its maiden voyage as it made such an impression on me. This painting is based on a fish-eyed lens photograph that I found on the web. I chose it for its unusual angle.

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

fields.title: Wheatfields near Argenteuil - Enamel miniature reproduction by Mark D Morris & Anthony Phillips
fields.caption:
A hand painted miniature reproduction, in enamel, of the painting by Sisley (1873). This was a collaboration with Anthony Phillips. The painting was one of the boxes in the series of limited edition replicas of the famous works of great masters done for Halcyon Days Enamels.

Actual size is 73mm x 51mm.

fields.title: Tropical Storm with a Tiger (Surprised!) - Enamel reproduction by Anthony Phillips & Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
An enamel miniature reproduction of the painting by Henri Rousseau (1891). This was a colaboration with Anthony Phillips. The painting was one of 75 limited edition enamel boxes commissioned for Halcyon Days for their Great Masters series. The painting by Rousseau was the 1994 box in the series.

Actual size is 73mm x 51mm.

fields.title: Villa - Miniature Enamel Painting by Anthony Phillips & Mark D Morris
fields.caption:
A miniature enamel painting, onto a large rectangular hinged enamel box, of a modern architectural property. The property is landscaped with a beautiful pond in the foreground. This was one of a dozen paintings that was done for an architect in USA, through Halcyon Days Enamels and was a collaboration with Anthony Phillips.

Actual painting size is 82mm x 62mm.

© MDMorris & Anthony Phillips.

fields.title: Waterfront Pair of Enamels - Commissioned Miniature Painting Enamel Box
fields.caption:
A commission for a pair of miniature painting, in enamel, of a waterfront property. Both paintings are the same size and are as close a match to each other as possible. It is, however, very difficult to make them match, since both are free-hand. One painting has the subject sitting slightly higher than the other, as you can see from the river bank level.

Actual painting sizes are both 82mm x 62mm.

All the Pieces with the nails
Alpha Piece of Enamel Cross

fields.caption: The Omega right-hand section of the cross

fields.title: Top Piece of Enamel Cross
fields.caption: The top section of the cross.

fields.title: Stem Piece of Enamel Cross
fields.caption: The stem piece of the enamel cross.

fields.title: Bottom Piece of Enamel Cross
fields.caption: The bottom section of the enamel cross.

fields.caption: home made nails

fields.title: Nails and my sore fingers
fields.caption: nails and sore fingers

fields.title: Whole cross from the top down view
fields.caption: Here's the finished cross from above

fields.title: Finished Cross with some perspective
fields.caption: An angled view of the finished cross.

fields.title: Signiature on the Stem Piece
fields.caption: I put my signature on all the pieces, this shows the one on the stem.

fields.title: Enamel Cross finish engraving
fields.caption: Here's the cross with the four top sections finished. I decided to leave the enamelling for these sections until I could do them all together. This way I could balance out the colours better.

fields.title: All the sections together with a black border
fields.caption: I've put all the sections together to get an idea as to how it will all look. Still the alpha section to do but nearly there!

fields.title: The right-hand arm drawn out
fields.caption: The gilding metal is painted with Chinese white water colour and I then draw the design onto the paint. This is the right-hand arm section of the cross

fields.title: Right-hand arm section mounted and ready to engrave
fields.caption: I've put the piece into a low melting plastic to hold it in place. The plastic is stuck on to a block of wood and the wood goes nicely into the vice. The vice and turntable, underneath, is made by Lindsay Engraving.

fields.title: Midway through engraving
fields.caption: I put in the design outline with a detailing 96 degree point graver. I make a light cut to begin with in case I make any mistakes! In this shot I've also removed some of the background, for which I use progressively larger flat gravers until its as flat as possible. The circular plant pattern around the omega was cut out with a thin knife-edge graver

fields.title: Right-hand section finished engraving
fields.caption: This is the section finished. I've dirtied the recessed sections a bit so it's easier to see the design.

fields.title: Close-up of the right-hand section and adjacent sections
fields.caption: Here's the section with the adjacent sections put together.

fields.title: Right-hand original pencil design up close
fields.caption: Taking a look again at the original design.

fields.title: Background inspiration
fields.caption: The green and white Fleur-de-lis background here is a possible pattern I could draw some inspiration from.

fields.title: Omega drawn out
fields.caption: Marked out the omega design onto a test piece.

fields.title: Engraving with Marigolds
fields.caption: My fingers can get quite sore, so here I'm trying some Marigold rubber gloves for protection.

fields.title: Omega test finished
fields.caption: Here's the test finished with the background put in

fields.title: Omega test and the current omega section put together
fields.caption: Here's the two pieces put side-by-side. I'm trying to imagine the test piece super-imposed on the other piece to get an idea if it looks right.

fields.title: Whole cross with central pieces complete
fields.caption: Here I've still got the two arm sections of the cross to engrave. This shot really highlights the difference in colour between the recently engraved gilding metal and the two arm sections, which have oxidized to a red colour.

fields.title: Whole cross with central pieces complete again but with some perspective
fields.caption: Just a shot showing the cross at this stage and the current state of my desk!

fields.title: Centre Piece close up
fields.caption: This is the centre piece set in soft plastic. The engraving stage is finished, this section took quite a long time!

fields.title: Cross after centre section is finished
fields.caption: All the sections put together after the centre section has been finished. I'm not going to enamel this now until the rest of the sections are all engraved.

fields.title: The top section is next
fields.caption:
I've marked out the design on the top section, so I'm ready now for the next stage.

I've moved the bottom piece to the side to get an idea as to how it'll look around the centre. I particularly wanted to be sure the border crosses flow nicely across the join.

fields.title: Cross with the bottom two sections finished
fields.caption: After the bottom two sections are finished it gives an idea as to what it'll all look like.

fields.title: Just the bottom two sections on their own
fields.caption: Checking the bottom two sections fit together OK.

fields.title: Middle section before applying the enamel
fields.caption: I just started applying some enamel and then realized I should take a photo first to show the stage.

fields.title: Ready for the first firing
fields.caption: The piece is placed onto the trivet ready to go into the kiln.

fields.title: In the kiln
fields.caption: Nice shot of the piece in the kiln. The temperature is at 800 degrees centigrade.

fields.title: Out of the kiln and cooled down
fields.caption: I think I've probably pickled this one too.

fields.title: Counter enamel on the back of the middle section
fields.caption:
I've put on some counter enamel onto the back of the piece because I observed it was beginning to bow along the length.

Later I developed a method of firing the pieces that minimized the warping in addition to using counter enamel: I pre- and post-heated the piece when firing.

fields.title: Applying enamel using a quill and a pointy tool
fields.caption: A quill was quite useful for scooping up enamel powder. The powder is applied wet.

fields.title: Just out of the kiln after a few layers of enamel
fields.caption: The colours on the enamel change as the piece cools down. Here you can see quite a different colour scheme.

fields.title: All the enamel applied and before grinding back
fields.caption: All the recesses have now got enough enamel in them so the piece can be ground back.

fields.title: Grinding back the enamel to flat
fields.caption: I use a flat stone and water to grind to the piece back to flat.

fields.title: Middle section after grinding back
fields.caption: After grinding back the enamel is matt.

fields.title: Middle section after the final firing
fields.caption: Just needs to remove the fire-scale of the metal and polish.

fields.title: Polishing with fine pumice
fields.caption: I use a slow-speed buffing wheel with finely ground wet pumice to do the first polish.

fields.title: Middle section after polishing
fields.caption: After polishing with pumice and rouge and cleaned up!

fields.title: Finished bottom section
Applying enamel to the bottom section
fields.caption: Here I'm halfway through putting on the enamel when I remembered to take a photo.

fields.title: First coat of Lapis Blue applied
fields.caption: Finished applying the first layer of Lapis Blue enamel (from Milton Bridge Enamels in Stoke on Trent, England).

fields.title: Red Border Applied
fields.caption: Applied the red around the border crosses. The red is call Arras Red and is also, like all the enamels used in this project, from Milton Bridge.

fields.title: First layer on the rose
Fluer de Lis with their first layer
fields.caption:
I'm not sure what the correct name for the scrolling flower is but I'll just call them scroll flowers!

No, update, they're called Fluer de Lis.

fields.title: After the first firing
fields.caption: It doesn't look so great straight after the first firing!

fields.title: After the second firing and cleanup
Check to see if it still fits the adjacent piece
fields.caption: After firing the metal can warp, so I'm a bit worried the join will become out of true. Here it's still good.

fields.title: Bottom section with the next layer of enamel
fields.caption: Showing the next layer of enamel to be fired.

fields.title: Check it still fits again
fields.caption: Yep, it still fits just fine!

fields.title: Grinding the bottom section flat
fields.caption: I do this stage of grinding by hand as machines can take off too much at once! It's important to see which parts need ginding more and apply just enough to get the surface flat.

fields.title: The bottom section out of the kiln after a few more layers
fields.caption: The grinding revealed that more enamel was needed in certain sections so I applied more enamel to the whole piece. This protects the border between enamel and gilding metal from oxidizing and discolouring the enamel.

fields.title: Bottom section counter enamel
fields.caption: Even though the metal sections are quite thick, I've applied counter-enamel to help guard against possible warping.

fields.title: Grinding back the bottom section and protecting the join edge
fields.caption: I tried this method of placing a sacrificial section next to the bottom section join to protect it against introducing a radius when grinding back. It was reasonably successful but I found the same could be achieved by just being a bit more careful!

fields.title: Bottom section showing matt enamel
fields.caption: This is after the final grinding back. The enamel, here, is all matt because it's had the top layer taken off with the grinding stone.

fields.title: Bottom section after the last firing
fields.caption: After the last firing the enamel is now glossy but the metal is oxidized. So we need to attend to this without destroying the enamel.

fields.title: Bottom section after wet pumice polish
fields.caption: After a wet pumice polish with a slow felt wheel.

fields.title: Bottom section after rouge polish
fields.caption: After using jeweller's rouge (iron oxide in tallow) on a fast felt wheel.

fields.title: Stem and bottom section finished engraving
fields.caption: This was quite something to have got a far as this and for it to be looking so good. I couldn't wait until it was enamelled

fields.title: Bottom piece marked out
fields.caption: In pencil, the lower piece is marked out onto Chinese white water colour.

fields.title: Lower and mid-section interface
fields.caption: Checking the lower section and the middle section join is good.

fields.title: Lower and mid-section pushed together
fields.caption: Yep, that's a good join!

fields.title: Bottom section finished engraving
fields.caption: I've just jumped right to the finished engraving, sorry about that, forgot to take any progress photo's for this. I just got totally absorbed!

fields.title: Stem section drawn out
fields.caption: Here's the next section all drawn out in pencil.

fields.title: Stem joined to bottom to see what it looks like
fields.caption: Just wanted to see what they look like together.

fields.title: Finished the rose on the stem section
fields.caption: I love this rose on the stem. As with many church window designs, this has twelve sections, symbolic of time and God's supremacy over it - if I'm right.

fields.title: Cross Shape
fields.caption: This is the shape of the cross that the customer has requested.

fields.title: Design style reference
fields.caption: This is the style the customer would like to emulate. It's from a Gospel cover created in the late 12th century, attributed to G. Alpais, Limoges.

fields.title: Design to make the cross in sections
fields.caption: The cross is too big to make all at once. For starters my kiln is too small but also making it in sections allow me to mess-up one section without causing disaster to the rest of the piece - hopefully this will not happen!

fields.title: My second design for the piece
fields.caption: The customer is happy with this design. It's challenging - but I do this to myself!

fields.title: Roughly cutting out the sizes of metal required
fields.caption: Very rough sizing up of the metal pieces. Only thing to be cautious of is not to make them too small.

fields.title: Lower piece cut to shape
fields.caption: I made this section on my Sherline Mill.

fields.title: Check it fits the design
Border Crosses Sampler
fields.caption: Experimenting with cutting some cross-shapes on the border. They've geen cut out with a graver and then the recesses filled with enamel, fired and ground back.

fields.title: Entwinning Patterns
fields.caption:
Some experimental entwinning patterns. From left to right we have:

1. design cut into yellow brass and filled with enamel

2. design cut into fine silver and filled with enamel (transparents are much easier on silver)

3. design created with thick cloisonné wires

4. design cut into copper.

fields.title: g-code example
fields.caption: Here's some of the g-code I wrote to cut out the shapes.

fields.title: Tool path for the piece
fields.caption: The tool path follows progressively tighter circuits around the shape.

fields.title: Sherline mill doing the cutting
fields.caption: Here's the little Sherlin Mill in action!

fields.title: Cutting the join right-angle
fields.caption: When the mill makes the circuit it puts a radius into what should be right-angle. So here I cut the right-angle into the join.

fields.title: Fine Filing
All the pieces layed out together
fields.caption: As you can see, I developed the bottom two sections to their finished state before I committed myself to making the rest of the sections. I needed to explore any problems, first, before going ahead with the rest.

fields.title: Home
fields.text:
Looking for beautiful miniature English Enamel Boxes?

Artist Enameller Mark D Morris can help turn your idea into a unique keepsake box.

Mark creates each box true to the Georgian craft of enamelling onto copper. Starting from sheet copper, a box is first formed into shape, then enamelled to a glossy finish. An original miniature painting is skillfully fused into the box, usually on the lid, requiring upto a dozen firings. The painting can be of any subject, for example, a house, yacht, car, a family pet or even a portrait.

Mark has completed commissions that were gifts for famous people including: Princess Diana, Queen Noor of Jordon, Elton John and Nick Faldo after his third win at the US Masters. Enamels are prized by collectors all over the world. A painting in enamel will never fade with time.
fields.image_caption: A lovely picture

fields.title: About Me
fields.text:
An artist enameller and craftsman living in Derbyshire, England, Mark Morris specialises in making enamelled decorative objects, usually by commission. In particular he has created and painted enamel boxes. Each box is crafted from basic materials: copper, brass, enamel and metal oxide paints to create a unique piece of artwork. Another commission saw the creation of a set of 26 enamelled cloissoné doorknobs, each designed by Mark and made to the customer's specifications.

From the beautiful spa town of Buxton in the Peak District, England, Mark began working with enamels the year before he was set to start university -- that year turned into five years!

During that time Mark served an apprenticeship in enamel painting and craftsmanship under the guidance of Anthony Phillips, the enamel artist for Halcyon Days Enamels. He completed many miniature paintings for Halcyon Days Enamels during this period. In fact the Miniature Paintings Gallery shows many of Mark's painting, such as the Tiger Moth biplanes, the Inside of the Royal Opera House and this one of a luxury yacht, which was the first commission he undertook.

Mark then took a ten year break from the craft and completed an undergraduate degree in Physics at the University of Birmingham, England, an M.Sc. by Research in Financial Maths and Stochastic Calculus at the University of Oxford, England (Exeter College, 2008) and plunged into the corporate world of energy supply and trading.

Now that Mark has returned to enamelling he is keen to exercise his freedom to explore the craft and, most importantly, go direct to the art lovers, collectors, art investors, gift seekers and people all over the world who appreciate exceptional craftsmanship and attention to detail.
fields.image_caption: It gives me great pleasure and satisfaction to
fields.image_description:
"It gives me great pleasure and satisfaction to use my knowledge of working with enamels and put my full energy into each piece of art I produce."

Mark Morris CGE

fields.title: Home2
fields.text:
Enamelling is the ancient art of fusing glass onto metal.

The enameller must gain an intuition for the way metal and glass behave, both independently and together;

thinking with the hands and with the head.

The temperatures of the fusing kiln may render an object to a glossy, beautiful finish, or destroy many days of fine work! This is the gamble the enameller takes every time a piece is fired.

Modern enamelling calls upon techniques both ancient and modern, bringing them together in a beautiful handshake.

This site documents my exploration of the art of enamelling, please feel free to explore and comment if you like!
fields.image_caption: finished enamel cross

fields.title: Home 3
fields.text:
I started out enamelling when I was seventeen years old, doing an apprenticeship in miniature painting. Since those early days I have challenged myself with all kinds of projects, but all with the underlying theme of making something!

I enjoy a challenge and I love making beautiful objects. With enamelling I'm always learning something new, even if it's something I've done many times before.

In my early days, whilst working under the guidance of a master enameller, I painted enamel miniature commissions onto a factory made enamel box. I have since learned how to make my own enamel boxes and many other objects, acquiring many new skills along the way.
fields.image_caption: centre piece close up

fields.title: Finished the Enamel Cross Project
fields.content:
Here's some close-ups of the pieces:

 

 

 

I made some nails out of gilding metal, the same metal that the cross is made from, I wanted to be sure that the nails would age in the same way as the cross. I'll write about making these nails in a different blog, suffice to say my method was a bit unkind on my fingers!

You can't really see here how sore my fingures were. I'll have to find another way to make these in future.

 

 

Here's the finished cross:

 

I put my signiature on all the pieces, here's the one on the stem piece
fields.lead: Here's the set of finished pieces that make up the enamel cross. I finished it a couple of months ago but I've not got around to updating this blog until now.
fields.excerpt: This is the alpha section of the cross.

fields.title: Enamel Cross Project (part 9)
fields.content:
I've not got round to updating the posts on this project for a bit. Here's how the cross looked after all the engraving was finished.

You can see here how the gilding metal tarnishes over time. The left-hand, alpha, section is the most recent and over time the metal turns more of a red-yellow colour, as with the centre and foreground sections. Since the end result is for the cross to look old this tarnishing is exactly what I want, so I won't lacquer the piece when finished.

Next stage is to show how the enamelling went!

fields.title: Enamel Cross Project (part 8)
fields.content:
I've finished the engraving for the penultimate section on the enamel cross. It's looking good! The twirly bits on this section were a bit tricky, those inside curves are really hard to get nice and clean cuts on.

Here's some photos on the progress of this section:

Here's the piece mounted in a low melting-point plastic, stuck onto a block of wood and put in the vice (The red coffee mug is a present from Taiwan, I love it and it keeps my coffee warm for ages!):

After a bit it looks like this. All of the design outline is engraved with a detailing 96 degree point graver. I aim to do a light cut to start with in case I make any mistakes. In this shot I'm also starting to remove some of the background, for which I use a flat graver. The circular plant pattern around the omega was cut out with a knife-edge graver.

Here's the finished engraving, with a bit of blackened background so the design is easier to see:

The section with it's adjacent piece:

 

On the design the alpha and omega are very important, in Christian art they symbolise the span of time. Alpha being the start of the Greek alphabet and omega being the end, the message being that God transcends time. I didn't want to overshadow the symbols so I wasn't too sure about the background to the omega. On paper I've put a design which is based on a reference from the book, shown below the next image:

the green and white Fleur-de-lis with green cross-pattern here:

So I did a quick sample to test how it would look just focusing on the centre of the circular section:

Here's a shot of the engraving in action, I've found old Marigold gloves quite useful for protecting against sore fingers!

Here's the finished sample, with some blackening in the recesses to pick out the design:

Putting the sample next to the section piece I'm pretty sure it would make the section look too busy. There's a lot of design going on in this section already and, I think, anything else would swamp the focus away from the omega.

I can always add extra design later if, after the enamelling, it's clear that something extra is required.

fields.title: Enamel Cross Project (part 5)
fields.content:
The enamel cross project is coming along well. I've got the lower two sections finished and cut out the four upper sections. The previous posts on this project are: part 1, part2, part3, part 4 and there's a new post on cutting out the metal sections here.

 

And just the bottom two finished sections:

There was quite a lot of shading to do on this section, especially on the white rose. I wanted it to blend in with the background blue but also pick out the white on the lower left and right (as seen when the cross is upright) fluer-de-lis.

Here's some photos of the enamelling stages from where I left off on the previous posts in part 3 (it's very similar to what I did in part 4):

Each layer of enamel goes on via wet laying, so I mix the enamel powder with water and apply it to the metal. After the first layer is applied, and before firing, it looks like this:

The piece is placed onto a kiln trivet and fired at a little above 800 degrees C so that, when the mass of metal absorbs the heat, the kiln temperature settles down at 800 degrees. I fire it for about 2.5 minutes, although sometimes 3 minutes if the kiln has not had time to soak.

This is the piece after it's been fired and cooled down:

 

I put a couple of layers of counter enamel onto the back at this stage to help minimise any bowing of the piece. My mix of scrap enamel is still giving a battleship grey!

 

After this I built up the enamel in all the recesses and started to create some of the blending of colours. The colour blends need to be established at a reasonable depth below the top surface of the final finish so that the colours don't burn out due to a thin layer. This is especially true with reds which tend to burn to a gray if they're not physically massive enough. I'm also going to grind back the top surface at the end so the colour scheme needs to be at least as deep as the maximum grinding depth.

I didn't take many photos of the intermediate steps but I think there were about a dozen firings in all.

Here's me adding extra enamel to some of the narrow blue sections and the red border, both of which were a bit tricky to get the enamel to flow into all the narrow spaces

I just thought I'd show this next bit as I find it quite interesting, when the piece comes out of the kiln the enamel colours are never the same as they will be when they cool down. The heat shows off a completely different colour scheme that can sometimes be quite inspirational, it's worth having a camera handy! Take a look at this, taken after the piece is nearly finished and just out of the kiln:

The main blue of the cross has turned turquoise and the flowers in the middle, orange!

It's important to make sure the enamel has fully filled all the recesses in the metal. For this I tend to over-fill and then grind back and re-fire. It can look rather scrappy at this stage even though it's nearly done!

Grinding back

After grinding I wash the piece with a toothbrush and then a glass brush just to be sure all the little bits of ground enamel and metal are cleaned away. This is what it looks like after the final grind back but before the final firing, you can see the enamel is matt.

I think I must have added some more red to the roses so the previous picture was probably not the final grind back after all! I tend to grind the piece back, gently, a few times before the final time in order to get a good idea how the colours are coming along. I'm pretty sure this next photo is after the final firing:

Next stage is a polish with wet pumice and jeweler's rouge. Here's the pumice polishing in action:

It's quite messy!

As before I've set the piece into plastic to minimize any radii that maybe created by the polishing wheel. After a while I found this set-up a bit tricky and took the piece out of the plastic but made sure the wheel was moving away from the edge and not into the edge of the piece.

Here's what it looks like after polishing with rouge and cleaning up:

fields.title: Enamel Cross Project (part 4)
fields.content:
This is the fourth part of my enamel cross project, for the previous part see here.

I've just finished the lower section of the cross, here's how it looks now (above):

 

I'm so pleased I didn't mess this stage up! I took plenty of photos along the way, so see below if you'd like to read on.

Starting the bottom section I'd engraved in the previous part I, first, cleaned and degreased it. Then I added some washed opaque powdered enamel to the differnent sections of the piece by wet laying. I started with the blue (Milton Bridge Lapis Blue O128)

 

The blue's all done, now apply the red around the border

Now the flower, I need to have a mix of white, red and pink for the petals so I've started here with the white to build up the sections. The background for the flower is opaque black.

The six fluer-de-lis and it's ready for it's first firing - all the surface area in the recesses is covered with enamel.

Here's how it looks after the first firing, and cooled for a bit. The exposed gilding metal has oxidised in the kiln and will need to be cleaned.

The piece is pickled in a hot bath of sulphric acid and, in this case, cleaned with an abrasive to reveal the yellow gilding metal. I used the abrasive to bring back the metal colour so I could select the enamel colours appropriately as I go. With some firings I won't use the abrasive as it's not necessary once I know what colours I'm using. So here's how it looks at this stage:

I did a check to see if the piece still fits with the next section, it does! So far so good!

Here's after the next layer of enamel

Fired and check again, still OK!

Grind back again as I still need to see the colour of the metal to get the overall feeling for the colour scheme. I set the piece into to plastic-wax to protect the edges from getting a radius during this procedure.

After a few more firings this is how it looks after it comes out kiln and then out of the acid bath. Pretty manky! Ughh. The red is probably copper oxide. The sulphuric acid takes a long time to disolve the red copper oxides. The black copper oxides are dissolved pretty quickly. It should look fine once it's all ground back again - errr hopefully anyhow!

Before grinding back, however, I noticed the piece was bowing. I was surprised since I'm using 4mm thick gilding metal so I thought this would be enough to resist the forces the enamel exerts. However I had engraved quite a lot of metal off the top so reducing the thickness. Anyway, whatever the reason, I counter enamelled the back of the piece to try and balance the forces. For this I use my pot of random bits of enamel powder which, at the moment, comes out in battleship grey:

Back to cleaning up the piece

This is cleaned up enough to see the design, I haven't completely ground the metal back to yellow as you can see some of the gilding metal is red. This, I believe, is due to a reduction gilding of the metal. The zinc in the metal is more volatile than the copper and so escapes from the surface of the metal during firing. This leaves a layer of copper on the surface of the gilding metal. I may be quite wrong mind you!

All the enamel, built up in the recesses, are nearly flush with the surface of the metal so almost there.

Here's after the final firing. Before firing I'd made sure all the enamel is flush with the surface and ground back to clean up all the enamel-metal interfaces.

I set the piece into plastic-wax again and polished with wet pumice on a slow felt wheel. This gives the metal a satin finish.

I also polished a bit more with jeweler's rouge. I could do more here but I think it's adequate for now, when all the pieces are done I'll need to polish them all at the same time to make them all coincide with each other. The gilding metal tarnishes over time and the whole finished piece needs to be consistent.

After cleaning off the excess rouge I come to this, my first finished piece!

fields.title: Enamel Cross Project (part 2)
fields.content:
Working with the bottom section, I cleaned the surface of the metal and painted on Chinese White. This allows me to draw the design in pencil onto the surface of the metal. Here's the main part of the design, without the border crosses.

 

Here's a photo of the design cut into the metal and the border crosses painted on. I also cut out the stem of the cross to make sure I could get the join between the bottom and stem pieces nice and neat:

After many hours of engraving I came to this:

I was going to go ahead and enamel it but then thought I should, at least, finish the stem section near to the join. I need to get the widths of the circle borders right on both joining sections. So here's the stem section of the cross with the design all marked out:

This section has quite a few complicated design features, in particular the rose on the right-hand-side. I'm relatively new to engraving and this will certainly be good practice! Here's how the cross is looking so far:

After many hours of cutting away metal I've got to this stage:

There were 84 petals, in total, to cut for the rose. I found getting a clean cut on the insides of curves to be very tricky. Somehow I managed it but couldn't really tell you how I did it! Most of the cutting is done with knife-shaped gravers, sometimes with a pointed bottom and sometimes flat. I try to use as large a flat bottomed knife-edged graver as possible to flatten out the recess cuts. If I were doing basse-taille enamelling technique, with transparent enamels, this would be more important to get a good relective surface off the metal to come through the enamel from behind.

The next post will be in a couple of weeks and hopefully should show some good progress!

fields.title: Enamel Cross Project (part 1)
fields.content:
I'm currently doing a project to make an alter cross, roughly 14 inches tall and 8 inches wide.

 

The cross should be in a style similar to that found in 12th century medieval religious art. In particular giving a similar feeling to this piece taken from page 113 of the Émaux du moyen âge book by Marie-Madeleine Guathier:

 

The piece above is done in champlevé enamelling, with quite a lot of engraving too. If I match the style of enamelling it will certainly help to give the right overall feeling for the cross.

A piece of work this large is far too big to go in my kiln and, also, I wouldn't want to do the piece in one go incase anything went wrong! I decided to make the cross in sections with the interface between sections made into part of the design like this:

Where each of the semi-circles is where there is a circle on the design:

The cross is to be made from brass. I have the Milton Bridge British Enamels set, these are tested for application to gilding metal, which is high copper content brass (10% zinc, 90% copper). I'm quite familiar with these enamels and used them to create the set of cloisonné door knobs last year.

 

I roughly cut out the gilding metal from 4mm plate:

and then, first, milled the bottom section into shape:

So far so good!

I'll cut out the other pieces after I've made a bit more progress with the bottom section. The application of heat during enamelling may change the shape slightly so I may need to give a little bit of extra brass at the interface to allow me to file the piece back into shape - we'll see!

fields.title: Experimental border crosses
fields.content:
I've been testing out how to create a border of crosses. The idea is to have a band of red enamel with small crosses along the band - giving a medieval look. Here's my experiment!

 

It looks like I'll need to engrave a bit deeper, the red has come out a bit grey so a deeper enamel layer should help. The blue is OK though. This particular piece has been done on gilding metal plate, 3mm thick and 40mm along the longest side. I still haven't done a proper test (like this) of the Milton Bridge British Enamel set on this metal yet - but planning to do fairly soon.

fields.title: Entwining Patterns
fields.content:
I've been experimenting with some champlevé and basse-taille enamelling. This entwining pattern is taken from a medieval enamel religious design. The samples, moving from left to right, respectively, are: a champlevé piece on standard brass, a basse-taille piece on fine silver, a cloissoné piece with fine silver wires on fine silver and, lastly, a champlevé piece on copper.

 

The brass piece did not take the enamel very well. The enamel would ping off rather unpredictably and dangerously. This was my first engraving piece and I dug out quite a depth to receive the enamel, probably about 2.5mm. This was way too deep and made it quite difficult to get good clean cuts on the inside of curves as the belly of the graver kept scraping the design.

The silver basse-taille piece was my favourite of the lot, the cutting out of the entwining pattern was comparatively clean and the transparent enamel bright and clear.

The cloissoné piece was soldered using hard silver solder and the border was cut out from silver strips and soldered. I used thick wires to bulk-up the main pattern but this just resulted in a crude-looking design. This happened because I had to grind the piece back quite a lot to allow for all the different wires to be at the same level and by then the design that was showing at the surface was not the one I had carefully put together!

The copper piece was quick to do and shows potential, there were no problems with the enamel compared to the brass.

fields.title: Cutting shapes out of 4mm gilding metal
fields.content:
For the enamel cross project I needed to cut out sections of the cross that could be placed together with a high degree of accuracy. The shapes are quite complicated having an inter-locking jigsaw-like joint, see below. For this purpose I decided to use my CNC Sherline mill and program some tool paths.

 

In this post I'll document the centre of the cross, which is the most complicated of all the sections.

I wrote the program for the tool paths directly in gcode, I just don't have any CAD or CAM software! Luckily for me I know a bit of maths, so the shape sections of the cross were abstracted, mathematically, and described by a set of parameters. This way I could reference the parameters for all the pieces, ensuring all the sections were consistent. For this particular section, I ended up writing a function for doing one side and then found I could do a 90 degree coordinate rotation (that's the g10 l2 p0 x0 y0 r90 bit) and re-use the same function to do the next side, woo-hoo! I'm exposing my geeky side! Here's a sample of it:

The program that finally materialized follows tool paths that incrementally get closer to the final shape, here's a schematic of the tool paths where each tool pass gets 1mm closer to the final shape. In the actual routine I used 0.1mm increments but they're too close to show up in a photo, so this is just to illustrate:

 

The cone is the location of the cutter and the lines show the path it will take.

In retrospect this program was not the best idea since the tool spends a lot of time not cutting any metal at the start of the routine, with only the inward semi-circle making any contact. A better approach would be to shave off the excess metal in straight lines first, then perhaps do the inward semi-circles next and finally finish with the routine above, but just without so many cycles. Anyway it worked but next time I think I can do better!

After checking the machine backlash, making fixing holes in line with the design, securing the blank metal piece to the milling table, making sure everything is aligned and axis zeroed etc, I ran the routine. It's always a bit nerve racking at first since, if anything is wrong, the cutter can easily crash into something. In this case I'm using a 2mm diameter carbide cutter and any crash results in the cutter just snapping off...as I found out! Here's the mill in action cutting out the cross middle section:

I used a feed rate of 300mm/min and, as mentioned above, a depth of cut of 0.1mm. The machine coped very well with this making good sized chippings.

The joint between sections of the cross have a 1mm flat section in between the two semi circles. The largest cutter I could use was therefore 2mm diameter. However this still leaves a radius whereas, for the joint to fit snugly,  I need a right-angle; so after the routine was finished I remounted the piece to cut the right-angle:

And then finished off by hand:

The other sections were done in a similar way. When my camera recharges I'll put a photo of all the pieces together with a little gap in between each piece to highlight the join. Hopefully I'll remember to do that!

I did remember! Here it is:

And here's with all the pieces together:

fields.title: Enamel Colour Tests
fields.content:
These are the set of enamel colours that I got from Milton Bridge's British Enamels set. It was quite a lot of work but worth doing. I've got an order for some cloisonné work and need some compatible non-painting colours. The top three rows are the transparent enamels and the bottom two rows the opaque.

The transparent enamels have been sieved to remove the finer particles and then washed to make them as clear as possible. The strips are done on silver since this reflects the light back through the enamel from behind. I've put a square (or whatever shape I happen to have cut out!) of gold foil at the bottom of the strip to see the difference when the enamel is on gold. Some of the reds come out a bit yellow when on top of silver but are nice and warm on the gold.

The opaque strips have copper as the metal base.

I should do two more rows for the opalescent colours, which will be from the fine particle transparent enamel. When the enamel grains are very small (less than 75 microns) then the vitrified enamel traps tiny air bubbles. The result is a semi-transparent, milky colour, quite useful in some applications!

fields.title: Fabergé-Style Egg
fields.content:
I had an interesting enquiry a few weeks ago to make a Fabergé-style egg. Initially the enquiry was about painting some miniatures on the base that would support the egg but expanded to include the whole piece.

I'd been wanting to try out a computer aided design (CAD) package called Blender for a while and this seemed like a good opportunity to do so.  I was amazed how life-like the finished rendered model looks. Blender allows scripting in Python computer language (which I like), so I was able to produce the egg shape from a mathematical formula, pretty cool! Here's the preliminary model design:

fields.title: Reproduction of Saba with a Glass of Red Wine by Fabian Perez
fields.content:
This shows the different stages in painting the reproduction of Saba with a Glass of Wine (original by  by Fabian Perez)

 

After the first firing, I didn't bother to smooth the dark background on this initial firing since when it's finished the background will be too dark to see any brush strokes.

After the second firing. The brush marks on the dark areas are disappearing.

After the third firing.

After the fourth.

After the 5th firing. This is not the best photo, there's too much reflected light. Anyway, I only took one before I started painting again so it will have to do!

The final painting, I could have gone on to make the blacks even darker and it may have benefited the painting. Overall I'm pleased with the result, it's captured the sexyness of the original.

fields.title: Move to Buxton and the New Workshop
fields.content:
We moved to Buxton in August last year after spending most of the year trying to find a suitable house. As seems to be normal these days, with moving house, we had plenty of stress and anxiety - enough for the next few years put together! The buyers of our house in Swindon threatened to pull out, the sellers of the house in Buxton were getting all agressive about us doing surveys (now we know why!) and the bank only just gave us a mortgage the day before the move.

 

Anyway we moved in (and by-the-way the removal company were fab so I'll give Advance Removals a mention) and since then we've changed the kitchen, put in new windows, loft insulation, new boiler, had the electrics updated, a new gas meter and put in a downstairs toilet, all in time for our new arrival, Adam, who was born on the 14th December last year. Phew! Quite a year! Hence this is the first blog post for a while.

The other project was to create a place for me to work, for this we plan to convert the garage into an enamelling workshop/studio. Well this is the progress to date:

2nd Nov 2014

Our garage is the left-hand one, it has rot in the beams and damp problems galore!

So to work! We employed the skills of brothers Shaun and Gavin Hall, who, as a piece of sound advice, call themselves 'Don't Do It Yourself'. Advice from which the previous owners of our house would benefit!

6th Nov 2014

The walls have all been pressure-washed to remove the old paint and plaster. The wall insulation is going in on the neighbour-side of the workshop.

 

7th Nov 2014

 

The walls at the back and on the left have been covered with GRS slurry waterproofing since these back onto a hill and are, effectively, underground. The right-hand side wall has been finished with water-resistant chipboard.

10th Nov 2014

The insulation goes in on the left-hand-side wall too, we're using 50mm Kingspan for the walls.

 

11th Nov 2014

Walls finished with water-resistant chipboard and a new mezzanine floor is put in - the old one was too rotten to salvage. Mind you we got quite a lot of fire-wood from it!

12 Dec 2014 (or thereabouts, the 12th is when I took the photo!)

The new ceiling goes in with the Velux windows. We've used 100mm of Kingspan for the roof, done in 75mm and 25mm separated layers. The 75mm sections lie in-between the wooden rafters and the 25mm sections overlap to cut out the thermal bridge. The original waterproof sheet has been replaced with a semi-permeable membrane. The outside wall needs cementing and the roof-wall interface sorting out as there's still water coming in at the back! We've put in plenty of electrical sockets too, I hate moving things around and extension cables can be a liability in a workshop.

13 Dec 2014 - 2 Feb 2015

Wind, rain and lots of snow! Any work has had to halt. In the meantime here are some nice pictures of snowy Buxton:

Our house

Wintery Hills from Corbar Cross

The School Run
fields.lead: We moved to Buxton in August last year after spending most of the year trying to find a suitable house. As seems to be normal these days, with moving house, we had plenty of stress and anxiety - enough for the next few years put together! The buyers of our house in Swindon threatened to pull out, the sellers of the house in Buxton were getting all agressive about us doing surveys (now we know why!) and the bank only just gave us a mortgage the day before the move.

fields.title: Doors for the workshop
fields.content:
We had Elite Windows (from Buxton) put in these bi-folding doors in the the workshop. They are really smart.

 

The frames are made from aluminium and have integral blinds within the glazing. They can open out to give a large entrance space. Here's what they look like from inside:

Oh yeah, I also painted the inside. I managed this just before my wife went into labour and had to go to hospital, literally just before!

We've used Elite Windows before to fit the uPVC windows in our house, the proprietor Alan Barnes and his team have been excellent on both occasions. They take pride in the work they do and if there are any problems after the job has finished then Alan sorts it out straight away, we'd recommend them to anyone.

fields.title: At the Heart of the Heat Exhibition
fields.content:
This photo of my enamel box is taken at the School of Jewellery, Birmingham UK, where it's on display in the Heart of the Heat Exhibition. I was there last Friday with my wife and son. We made quite a day of it, going to the Christmas markets in the centre of Birmingham, then going to see my sister and her partner for dinner before driving to Buxton to see my Mum, Dad and little sister.

 

The exhibition features work from many other artists using a variety of enamelling styles. Here you can see examples of cloisonné, champlevé, basse taille, etching, enamel painting, guilloché and some large enamel works. Here's the exhibition as seen from the first floor:

You can see the school's forge in the background, what a great facility! Lastly, here's a pic of the proud artist next to the successful piece.

fields.title: My Page in the Heart of the Heat Exhibition catalogue
fields.content:
Here's my page in the Heart of the Heat catalogue, I hope you can read the description.

Here's the glossy front cover:

I was expecting to be only one of hundreds of people exhibiting but was really surprised to find that I was one of only 43 people from the Guild of Enamellers and British Society of Enamellers that was featured in the catalogue. There were also 14 invited enamellers and 4 manufacturers (W H Darby, Fattorini, Gladman & Norman and Toy, Kenning & Spencer) taking part in the exhibition. I was blown away by some of the work on show. In particular I liked the work by Phil Barnes. My work was exhibitied in a cabinet especially for enamel painting, along with works from Gillie Hoyte Byrom, Francis Clark, Jeanne Crosse, Susan Davies and Penny Gildea.

At the private viewing, on the 13th November, I met with many of the other craftsmen and artists. I was particularly interested in the cloisonné work since I've got a big commission involving cloisonné at the moment, I thought I might get some tips! There was a talk by Ruth Ball about her enamelling which was really informative and I met my Guild of Enamellers' regional representative Jeanne Crosse. Since it was my first time at the School of Jewellery Jeanne showed me where to go to get to the lecture theatre to hear the talk by Ruth.

The exhibition is at the School of Jewellery, Vittoria Street, Birmingham, UK and runs from the 11th November to the 13th December 2013. Please go if you can. It's only open weekdays from 10.00am until 4.00pm, which, unfortunately, makes it quite hard to go and see if you work normal office hours.

fields.title: Enamel Boxes at the Mall Galleries
fields.content:
Last Wednesday I visited the Mall Galleries where my enamel boxes are on display in the Royal Society of Miniature Painters, Sculptors and Gravers Exhibition. I met up with my friend Valerie who visits the galleries around London far more frequently than me. Valerie was also a good friend of the late Anthony Phillips and I was glad for her support for this, my first, exhibition.

 

It was great to see my paintings in the exhibition with all the other miniatures. The enamel boxes were put into the sculpture category and were displayed at the back of the gallery in a glass cabinet, here's a photo:

And here's a close up of the enamels:

And here's one of the proud artist!

Right next to my boxes where some sculptures of ducks done by Philip Nelson, these scooped three awards! They were very good, and finely painted. Quite handy having an award winner next to my paintings as more people will make the effort to come and look in my general direction, albeit at the ducks!

I also met Gillie Hoyte Byrom, a fellow enameller, and viewed the three fine portraits of musicians that she was presenting at the exhibition. It was Rosalind (Roz) Pearson who introduced Gillie to me. Roz is an exceptionally tallented miniature painter whose landscapes I'm am quite envious of, espicially her ability to paint trees. I also saw the miniature portraits done by Elisabeth Meek and thought they were exceptionally good, I'm not surprised she's won so many awards. They were pretty inspiring and has given me the urge to improve for next time!

fields.title: Successful Entries for the Royal Society of Miniature Painters Sculptors and Gravers Exhibition
fields.content:
All five of my entries for the Royal Society's exhibition have been accepted. This is really the best that I could have hoped for.

At first I thought that none of my pieces had been selected. Later I found all five codes listed on the Society's website under the Sculpture heading! I guess because these are enamel boxes they need to be exhibited in a similar way to sculpture.

The one above is Baby Orla (62mm x 82mm)

The other four enamels, with their titles, are as follows:

 

Louis Armstrong (62mm x 82mm)

 

Classic Chrysler Car (82mm x 62mm)

 

The Space Shuttle Discovery (62mm x 82mm)

 

A Villa in the Portuguese Algarve (82mm x 62mm)

fields.title: Painting an Enamel Box Lid with a picture of Louis Armstrong
fields.content:
I use on-glaze enamel paints and mix them with oil and turps substitute to get the right consistency. The turps thins the paint down and the oil acts as a binder. I'm currently using lavendar oil, although I'm finding this a bit thin for some purposes, like stippling.

The important thing is to minimize the number of firings. To do this I aim to cover the whole piece with paint for each firing, resisting the tempation to focus on just one area. Each firing typically takes about a minute at 800oC. In this case the enamel lid was quite thin so it only needed 50 seconds.

I recently painted a portrait of Louis Armstrong onto an enamel box lid. I took photos after each firing stage.

Here's after the first firing

The important thing here is to size the painting up, get all the right proportions and not do anything that is irreversible! It's pretty much impossible to erase any mistakes with enamel. It's possible to paint over but it may take many firings to disguise the mistake.

Here's after the second firing:

The aim here was to build up the shadow and establish some general colour. Also it's time to define the shapes a bit better.

After the third:

This time it got over fired a bit, the colour is starting to fade a little although it's difficult to tell from the photo. No problem, though, in this case it added a little softness to the painting but I'll need to add more colour to compensate.

This is after the fourth:

The trumpet is not quite there yet, but it's coming together overall.

Fifth:

Just a bit more colour agian, especially in the background. For this I stippled the paint with a pad to give the dotted effect.

And finally the 6th firing:

Here I finally got the trumpet the way I wanted it, it needed darkening at the front. The finished enamel box can be seen here.
